questions.question_text:
A company recently implemented a new cloud storage solution and installed the required synchronization client on all company devices. A few months later, a breach of sensitive data was discovered. Root cause analysis shows the data breach happened from a lost personal mobile device.
Which of the following controls can the organization implement to reduce the risk of similar breaches?

discussion.content:
C
Application containerization would encrypt the cloud data residing on the device. So even if the device wasn't FDE, the cloud data would be secure.

Maybe: B. Cloud storage encryption ?
If the data is encrypted in the cloud, and the sync client puts the data on the device, maybe the data on the device will also be encrypted?

I'm guessing your angle is unplug the drive from the device to gain access to it. Hence you said hardware anti-tampering. 
Firstly, you can infer from the question that the data is not sitting on the device but in the cloud. hardware antitampering doesn't seem like the choice to make straight away.
Second, the cloud storage solution was for company devices which have sync client installed. The breach happened from a "lost personal mobile device". Meaning there are other controls missing. 
Conclusion now, any device with the sync client can access the cloud storage. 
Losing a personal device which access to the sensitive data in the cloud through a sync client that has caused a breach. Likely that the issue is weak authentication on the personal device

comments.content: Since there is a sync client, wouldn't the data be both on the device, and in the cloud?

discussion.content:
A
Biometric authentication is much more secure than PIN or passcodes. Provided answer is correct.
There is always going to be a password on the mobile device, so biometrics don’t solve this. Because this is a lost device, I would say hardware anti tampering.

comments.content: Could you give some examples of hardware anti tampering that would useful in this situation? Would you have to know the device is missing to use such technologies?

questions.question_text:
A vendor develops a mobile application for global customers. The mobile application supports advanced encryption of data between the source (the mobile device) and the destination (the organization's ERP system).
As part of the vendor's compliance program, which of the following would be important to take into account?

discussion.content:
B. Export controls

The AIO book (p. 20-21) touches on "export controls and legal requirements." The compliance program in the question needs to ensure the application meets legal requirements of international data transmissions (managing and controlling how data is exported/travels internationally).

I thought option D (privacy policy) could have been the answer, but I think this can possibly fall under export controls.

B - Export Control
Advanced encryption + global = export control

READ THE FUCKING QUESTIONS GUYS

"Compliance program" 

B

comments.content:
But why is it needed?
> The mobile application supports **advanced encryption** of data between the source (the mobile device) and the destination (the organizations ERP system).
The data is already secure. 
Also, tokenization is not typically something that is "taken into account" as part of a "compliance program."

This question doesn't mention it being important to protect any sensitive credit and debit card information. This question seems to have a focus on the app being global and needing to be compliant. I think B is a better option.

discussion.content: Given answer is correct. Tokenization is a new emerging standard for mobile transactions, uses tokens to protect cardholders’ sensitive credit and debit card information

Any chance this could be: D. Privacy policies ?
The only reason I think it could be privacy policies is because the question makes a point of specifying "global" customers. I know there are special requirements regarding privacy when working internationally.

comments.content: The question also does not specify these are BYOD devices, we can safely assume these are company assets and only need a patch agent installed on them.

discussion.content:
C is correct
Device quarantining does the opposite of making sure the users can access the network and meet security requirements, it bars users from the network. You'd have to use something like an Identity Services Engine or Update Agent to validate software versions and force users to run the correct version before being allowed on.
D. Device quarantine - The MDM will enforce a policy to exclude a device from access if it does not meet the minimum patch levels. I am not sure patch management is available in an MDM.

comments.content:
The question says what should be done to ensure the devices can access the network. Quarantine would prevent the devices from doing so. 

That's what I'm leaning towards. Patch management

questions.question_text: A recent assessment identified that several users' mobile devices are running outdated versions of endpoint security software that do not meet the company's security policy. Which of the following should be performed to ensure the users can access the network and meet the company's security requirements?

A security engineer is working to secure an organization's VMs. While reviewing the workflow for creating VMs on demand, the engineer raises a concern about the integrity of the secure boot process of the VM guest.
Which of the following would BEST address this concern?

discussion.content:
Maybe: A. Configure file integrity monitoring of the guest OS?
The question specifically states "concern about the integrity." vTPM seems like a useful thing. But I am not sure I understand how "vTPM on a Type 2 hypervisor" is the way to address a concern about the integrity of secure boot.

comments.content: The key here is the secure boot process.

choices.D: Protect the memory allocation of a Type 1 hypervisor.
choices.C: Only deploy servers that are based on a hardened image.
choices.B: Enable the vTPM on a Type 2 hypervisor.
choices.A: Configure file integrity monitoring of the guest OS.

questions.question_text:
When implementing a penetration testing program, the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) designates different organizational groups within the organization as having different responsibilities, attack vectors, and rules of engagement. First, the CISO designates a team to operate from within the corporate environment.
This team is commonly referred to as:

comments.content: Would the Blue team have attack vectors, or rules of engagement? I would think that only the Red team would have those.

discussion.content:
A
The Blue Team would operate from inside the organization and attempt to track/defend against The Red Team, who would behave as external threats. From outside the organization. Red and Blue.

Maybe: B. the white team ?
"different organizational groups within the organization as having different responsibilities . . . CISO designates **a** team to operate from within the corporate environment. 
I am thinking there may be a few red teams, and a few blue teams, but only one white team. 
Different organizational units are treated separately in many ways. One unit is going to be attacked very differently than another unit. So each unit will have to defend in different ways. 
But you could have one white team, and that would operate "within the corporate environment."

I would choose D but.....
This is a really really poorly worded question. Based on the wording in the question, one has to assume that the under the pen test program the CISO has assigned the team pen testing with different attack vectors starting with internal pen test rather than an external one. This is possible in real life as companies sometimes have internal red teams and others hire externally. Bottom line is that CISO or whoever hires them has a limited budget/resource/time and can choose internal or external attack and/or blackbox whitebox or graybox type tests.

comments.content:
What ticks me off is: I know about red/blue/white teams. I know what they do, and how they operate. 
But I am not sure of any of the answers given, because I cannot be certain that I am understanding the question. 
Most everything before the last two sentences might not matter. It might be a red herring. The real question might be this:
When implementing a penetration testing program . . . First, the CISO designates a team to operate from within the corporate environment. This team is commonly referred to as:
I thought the Red team would typically not be "from within the corporate environment?"

discussion.content:
Maybe "read team" is just a misspelling? Maybe they meant "red team?" 
I think the answer is "white team" because the white team does operate within the corporate environment. But, this is a very poorly worded question. White team does not have attack vectors, or rules of engagement. White team are referees. Also, there are no operations team, read teams, or development teams, in such an exercise.
